intro: Caperonia palustris, commonly known as the swamp caper, is a flowering plant belonging to the family Ericaceae. It is native to wetland habitats in North America, particularly in the eastern United States. The plant typically grows in moist, acidic soils and is often found in bogs, swamps, and along the edges of ponds. It produces small, bell-shaped flowers that are usually pink or white, and it has a low, mat-forming growth habit. Caperonia palustris plays an important role in stabilizing wetland ecosystems and providing habitat for various invertebrates.
